Natásha expected Bolkónski all day after her talk with her mother.
Bolkónski did not come to Natásha.
On the second day, Bolkónski did not come to Natásha.
On the third day, Bolkónski did not come to Natásha.
Pierre did not come to Natásha on those days.
Natásha did not know that Prince Andrew had gone to see his father.
Natásha could not explain Prince Andrew's absence to herself.
Three weeks passed.
Natásha had no desire to go out anywhere.
Natásha wandered from room to room like a shadow.
Natásha was idle and listless.
Natásha wept secretly at night.
Natásha did not go to her mother in the evenings.
Natásha blushed continually.
Natásha was irritable.
Natásha thought that everybody knew about her disappointment and was laughing at her and pitying her.
Natásha's inward grief wound to her vanity intensified her misery.
Natásha came to her mother and tried to say something.
Natásha suddenly began to cry.
Natásha's tears were those of an offended child who does not know why it is being punished.
The countess began to soothe Natásha.
Natásha, after listening to her mother's words, interrupted her, saying that Prince Andrew had just come and then left.
Natásha's voice trembled.
Natásha nearly cried again.
Natásha recovered.
Natásha went on quietly.
Natásha said that she does not at all want to get married.
Natásha said that she is afraid of Prince Andrew.
